- Faking about customers services is the priority but actually setting targets on upwelling Apple care + to the customer with pressure, and most worse NO commission will be offered even if you reach or exceed targets.
- In the end, NUMBERS are everything to Apple in Hong Kong
- and more.

headline: Specialist
status:
20 October 2016
"Specialist"
2.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: You can enjoy lots of Holidays and welfare obviously.
cons:
Most of your promotion and rotation opportunity is based on the feedback result from the customer. Which is so hard to get even a feedback in the Asian culture. I have a colleague had been told that if he would not get 4 promoters (positive feedback) he will be terminated.

if you are working in retail, Apple probably the best in the market. But if you are finding a meaningful job, which you may passionate about. I suggest you firstly, understand what you like to do. Secondly, consider apple as an normal retail store. please.
advice_to_mgmt: Change the system give incentive to a customer. Put NPS into a store wide not a personal matter.

headline: The Ultimate in International Retail Career Experience.
status:
28 August 2014
Helpful (1)
"The Ultimate in International Retail Career Experience."
4.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: The opportunity to be part of something big in the history of Retail--and to witness it first hand, in the Asia Pacific region.
cons:
An defaulted experience in the change of politics at the company, at a Retail level--changed culture and mismanagement. Now it is definitely has changed, guaranteed. I, personally, wanted to move on, felt I could do more and develop better in a another company. 

Work-life balance was amazing, compared to industry standards--especially in Hong Kong. I would definitely say that benefits in this job is definitely premium status.
advice_to_mgmt:
A discussion of hiring and developing, internally--is way better than hiring externally outside of the company, if looking for generation development. The internal staff is way smarter and capable to handle the stresses and opportunities better, since the training is still great. 

Otherwise, couldn't have asked for such great talent and passion hired by Apple.

headline: Great company with great benefits
status:
2 February 2021
"Great company with great benefits"
4.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Current Employee
pros:
Colleagues are friendly and nice
Awesome benefits
Great work environment
cons:
Increased focus on minimum sales and numbers for specific services.
Less focus on human connection.
advice_to_mgmt: Rather than focusing on the numbers and setting a hard target to achieve them with, try to understand employee's point of views and to focus more on the customer experience. Sales and numbers will follow when an employee is happy working and providing a great experience for a customer. Sometimes it feels like we are trying to upsell or push a product and service just so we can hit our minimum requirements for the week, rather than focusing on the experience which is detrimental to the customer journey as well as employee happiness. The focus on human connection feels like its no longer there, compared to a few years back.

headline: Awesome
pros:
-tuition reimbursement is substantial 
-potential to do a career experience in corporate
-the best coworkers of all time 
-leadership that cares (for the most part) 
-free weekly covid tests sent to my house 
-401k match 100% up to 6% of your paycheck after 5 years. 
-great discounts on hero products 
-free Apple Music, iCloud storage (200GB), Games, and Apple TV 
-understanding leadership who gives you so many chances especially if youâ€™ve been at the company for a while and you work hard. 
-$100 a month for commute 
-reallllyyy good health insurance. I can see my dentist for a cleaning 4 times a year if I want 
-lots of resources for learning through Apple
cons:
-way too much white leadership. 
-way too few women in leadership and technical roles. 
-lots of white men in leadership promoting other white men to leadership, over and over. 
-leadership should take into account the opinion of a coworkers peers before making decisions on promotions.
advice_to_mgmt: Take notice of the people who are really trying their best and working hard. Take notice of which employees are truly liked and which arenâ€™t. Employees who are liked by their peers and work hard get overlooked a lot because leadership is often distracted by employees who appear to have a very â€˜highâ€™ performance by numbers, and very, very poor relationships with their peers and with their customers.

advice_to_mgmt: You could have 100 good calls in a row and as soon as you get one bad call, management is all over you. They give zero support to employees and automatically assume you did something wrong, even when people are goign to rate you bad no matter what. Management has a mentality that they "know better" so they think anytime you have a bad call, that if they were on the line it would have been a 'good' call, which is often not the case.

headline: Challenging.
status:
13 January 2021
"Challenging."
4.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Current Employee
pros: The lack of organization and support, high pressure work and all-work-no-play culture means that within a few years here you will be independent and really good at your job. Compensation is generous for invested employees, and the products themselves are interesting to build.
cons: Most engineers are professional and helpful, but there is no training culture or push for code methodology apart from general product-related guidelines - these subjects are left to the manager's discretion. So there is too much room for improvement in work efficiency, causing actual work to slow to a crawl. It's like the Israel section is still recovering from its chaotic time as a bunch of startups stiched together.
advice_to_mgmt: Push for more code reviews and teamwork, it will allow the team to spend less time on repetitive tasks and innovate more.

headline: Group think to advance

3.0

Current Employee
pros:
- OK pay
- great name on a resume
- nice people
- easier to get into as temp winter employee
- stock is great, especially since they keep it affordable for entry level employees
- ok health unless your full time
cons:
- you must be a super energetic cheer leader for Apple to advance
- above requirement makes group think a big issue; hard to find original ideas
- sensitive; every day I work in fear because I never know what new extreme left policy they utilize will trigger false accusations 
- the need to appease identitarian extremists is so great I am regularly and falsely accused of discrimination
- huge lack of diversity. Everyone looks different, but thinks the same. It is kind of like the stepford wives. Lots of smiles and niceness, just donâ€™t mention anything politically moderate or right leaning.
- because of all of the above, it isnâ€™t uncommon to see employees emotionally and verbally abuse other employees for taking a stand for something that doesnâ€™t align with identitarian intersectional ideology.
advice_to_mgmt: Create a DNA for conservatives. Apple says they are â€œfor everybodyâ€ in their values but fail miserably for people who are more conservative leaning. There have been so many people Iâ€™ve known who would say, â€œI am just using this placeâ€ or â€œthis place will never accept me.â€ Lots of talent is lost in this manner, and having people who have been successful yet conservative at Apple guide you through understanding and navigating the terrain will help keep some talent. Though, because of the above cons, I seriously doubt Apple could find any leaders who are either conservative or will admit to being so.

headline: Good Resume Builder
status:
12 January 2021
"Good Resume Builder"
3.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: Benefits, sales experience, tech experience, discounts, small sample of leading corporate culture, great staff to work with. My immediate reporting manager was amazing as was my store manager/HR. Most of the time sales were easy.
cons: INADEQUATE TRAINING. I was someone who started without an abundance of tech knowledge. My team taught me something new every day, all day. Normally a good thing but not great when the store is swamped (which frequently happens) and you're essentially on your own. Still retail, Same challenges with any other retail position: Unrealistic hours (cant exactly be helped. Weekends and nights), Not enough Pay to scrape by (On the higher side of retail though.) "Unspoken" sales/business intro/apple accessory + service quotas. Zero incentive to achieve a top position in any previously mentioned categories, aside from recognition. Any advancement WILL require some outside education. Apple/ Store sponsorship does exist to some varying degree. Apple corporate and Apple retail are two ENTIRELY different entities. Just because an employee enters the Apple "eco-system" at a base level doesn't mean that the employee may have a better chance of securing a corporate career, even with an adequate curriculum vitae and professional experience. Experiences seem like more of a way to "tease" employees rather than show a glimpse of a future career.
advice_to_mgmt: Hit or miss. Mainly issues at corporate levels rather than direct store issues. Management styles shouldn't vary wildly manager to manager. Please keep employees up to speed and help them use outside sources to train. "Hello" and training modules exist but these tools are useless without ample time to actually study the material. Get some hands on physical basics (computer internals), new phones to practice basic iOS diagnostics/resets. SET ADEQUATE time aside for new hires to learn, I cannot stress this enough. The last thing you need is a new hire sheep waiting for help with a quick fix while management is dealing with unruly customers. It will only benefit in the long run. Some favoritism took place. We all know resources are limited and management at a store level won't change the entire company, but some more measures need to be implemented. For everyones sanity.

headline: It's Okay...
status:
9 January 2021
"It's Okay..."
3.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: At times it can be fun. You will most likely end up working with some really intelligent and great people. The company strives to build comradery within each retail location and if you happen to be working at a store other than home store, you will find that for the most part, the culture is the same. You really can build some great friendships.
cons: The training is laughable. While the topic is always a source of discussion, the time allotted to learn and study is minimal and is usually plagued with interruptions. Management is top heavy and like any workplace, managers can be ego driven. It's a definite paradox in that the company mandates "Daily Downloads". For the most part these are drink the koolaid and cheer leading sessions and you will stand out if you don't participate. Often a lead or a manager will go over what was in a company made video that was distributed to retail locations as a means of motivation. You will soon learn that what is stated in the videos is often not practiced in your store... It can be a toxic and co-dependent nightmare depending on your management team (like any workplace) but at the very the least you will be trying to figure out why there are so many managers per store. The company likes to tell you that Apple retail store are more than retail... The pay structure is often held up to/based on retail pay, but there is a lot to learn and processes and products are constantly changing. You are graded on every single transaction via customer feedback. You will be encouraged and possibly singled out if you do not share enough about yourself with your co-workers and your managers. To summarize, it's hit and miss and more overwhelming instead of engaging. You most likely will not learn as much as you would like to unless you are willing to learn outside of your paid time and the pay, well, you'll probably fall into the category of living pay check to pay check. If you want to really use your mind and have an engaging learning environment I suggest looking elsewhere. On the other hand, there is ALWAYS a lot of hype about working for Apple and how difficult it is to get a job there and how Cinderella like of a place it is to work at... By the end of your on boarding they will have convinced you that you are part of an elite group. Take it however you want to... One of the big questions I think a lot of people have is if you can get a corporate job if you get hired for a retail position. The answer: yes, but like any other workplace you will need to be a savvy political player.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to and respect your people.

headline: Indian Managers Will ONLY Hire Other Indians
status:
23 January 2021
"Indian Managers Will ONLY Hire Other Indians"
1.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: Cutting edge technology, located in the heart of Silicon Valley
cons: If you are not Indian, your days are numbered. Unfair BIAS against non-Indian employees.
advice_to_mgmt: The demographics of Apple are shifting, with 95% plus of engineers being of Indian descent. If a company in Silicon Valley were to hire 95% Caucasians, this would be unacceptable, of course. But if an equal percentage of Indians takes over a company, oh well, this makes the company "Diverse", right? At Apple, Indian managers have successfully taken over the company (at least in the fields of IT, engineering and computer software). They want to reserve the rich, highly-coveted Silicon Valley Lifestyle for themselves, their relatives, and people of their own Caste who are stuck back at home in Tamil Nadu or some other Southern province. They implicitly believe that native-born Americans are undeserving of this privilege. The Indian managers seek to enforce this policy by upholding a double standard: the bar is very low when they are helping their own to climb the corporate ladder, but the bar raises to an impossibly high level when it comes to native-born American citizens. They see nothing wrong with helping their under-qualified uncles, aunts and cousins to get jobs, while throwing native-born Americans under the bus. If you are not Indian, you don't stand a chance. Apple management has allowed this to happen, they have enabled a system that is extremely discriminatory against Americans, yet they want Americans to purchase their products. But if Apple only wants to hire Indian, then perhaps only Indians should buy their iPhones and iPads, and Americans should think Android instead. If this practice of dismissing extremely qualified and talented American engineers to make room for inferior Indian engineers from specific desired Castes and regions (Tamil Nadu), Apple is going to lose its marketplace lead and engage in a slow (or possibly more rapid) decline. This problem has already gotten way, way out of hand. The time is ripe for corrective action to be taken (either by Apple itself, or if not, then by means of government intervention). NOTHING is diverse about an engineering staff that is 95% South Indian, where access to a job is 100% controlled by a biased, ignorant manager who uses lack of 'skills' and 'fit' as a pretext to weed out employees who have undesirable ethnic backgrounds.

headline: There for a good time, not a long time
status:
23 January 2021
"There for a good time, not a long time"
1.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros:
- Product discount 
- Plenty of shifts 
- Comfortable casual uniform 
- Share program 
- Bit of comical banter amongst the team
cons:
- A very competitive environment. 
- Favouritism towards the wrong people. There is a strong culture of promoting those whom talk the most and peacock around the shop. 
- Ostracism from the managers. 
- Constant culture brainwashing.
- No say in the roster you receive each week. Often horrible shifts that create no work life balance. 
- Download meetings every day targeted for team members who want to show off their public speaking skills, which you have to sit through. 
- You soon realise its just temp job after you experience the day-to-day culture environment.
advice_to_mgmt: HR need to be more on the ball with the above mentioned cons and the company really need to start hiring right people for stores instead of so many peacocky show offs.

headline: Excellent pay and perks but not great culture
pros:
For any position you get awesome salary. Additionally, you get discounts on Apple products upto 17 % for friends and family on every product but you are limited to 10 products of each category(10phones, 10 airpods, 10 macbooks etc). And for your personal use you get 27% but limited to one product of each category. 
You also get 500USD credit additionally for every 2 years. 

You get 15 % discount on stocks but you can just buy them you can only opt to buy shares from your salary and the company will automatically deduct the amount from the salary. It is similar to VPF where you choose the percentage of deduction. Here you can only choose from 0 to 10% of your salary to be invested in shares. You cannot additionally buy elsewhere for 15% discount. 
You can also avail 155000 INR for any educational courses that you need to do. 
During the pandemic they also reimbursed for furniture.
cons:
The work culture is good not that interactive. All of the decision making is in Cupertino(HQ) and if you want to contribute to the process then it is not possible. You don't even have someone in the leadership to collaborate with. They give the work and you have to do it, contrary to Amazon where if you propose something and the leadership finds it impactful then they give you the ownership and also collaborate with you on that idea/project. If you want to just work and leave then its great for you but if you want to do something more apart from usual work then the aforementioned applies.

The educational courses mentioned need to be relevant to your work that you are doing at Apple and if your work and the educational course are not in the same field you won't get reimbursed. 
Furniture reimbursement is limited to 100 USD(7000INR) which is quite less. You either get a good table or an ergonomic chair but not both. 

There are not much ad-hoc tasks apart from the daily work which is pretty monotonous and tiring.

For this particular role(grading analyst) they give you iMac and not Macbooks to work so WorkFromHome is not allowed under ideal conditions. Due to the pandemic the iMacs were transported to everyone's homes and WFH was established for the team. 
There is no transport provided by the company but that's manageable since they are paying a lot.

headline: Yeah sure
pros: Apple strives to make sure that you are a priority along with the customer. With new guidelines regarding inclusivity, Apple is becoming a safer environment for people of any race, gender, or sexual identity.
cons: There is really a lack of communication between management and corporate. They don't typically visit unless its for press or launch and if there are issues they are slow to fix it. For years out HVAC has had issues and this summer, during a pandemic, record-breaking heat wave, and fires our ac wasn't working. Some days it would get up to 85-90 degrees inside our store and it sucked. it took weeks to get fixed and we still have problems. Occasionally it'll smell like smoke inside because a belt is broken, and now with winter coming the heating doesn't work that well.
advice_to_mgmt: Transparency with the staff and clear communication so guidelines are followed are important

headline: Equal Parts Challenge and Reward - Not for everyone
pros: The benefit package is excellent, even for part-time employees. 401k, stock options, medical/vision/dental, a wide range of product discounts, and other benefits. You get to work with a lot of high-functioning, like minded people, which means you'll make a lot of friends. The pay is competitive for a retail job.
cons:
The job is as challenging as it is rewarding - and as of late the challenges outweighed the rewards. Pay is not negotiable and superior sales performance is given little to no consideration during your 'merit increases' which are 3.5-5% per year, once a year. 

The high customer traffic, high noise, bright lights, and being on your feet for 8-9 hours can be physically taxing. Full-time work during holiday and launch season can be draining. The customers in my area were typically high-maintenance types and were often difficult to deal with.

Advancing in the company is more about playing the political game than how well your actual job is being done, which frequently results in people being advanced to management and leadership positions who do not have the right hard skills or competencies for the task. A good leadership team can really shape your experience at Apple as much as the work you put into it.
advice_to_mgmt: It was a different game 5-7 years ago; We took care of customers more and focused less on sales metrics. Be genuine in your approach. Be more discriminating in current and future hires and promotions.

headline: Call Centre Job
pros: Most of the people there are amazing. The benefits are good, and so is working from home although thats not much of a novelty anymore post-Covid
cons: There is a lot of politics, which was a surprise since everyone works at home. Progression can be limited to who you know and who you are lucky (or unlucky) enough to have as a team leader. The pay is actually very very low for a job that requires quite a bit of technical advice. There are MANY metrics.

headline: So-So
pros:
- New ideas are encouraged
- Coworkers and peers are incredibly smart
cons:
- The Apple culture is changing for worse. What was once a prestigious tech company who had a passion for innovation and people has disappeared and turned into a powerhouse of labor exploitation. Expect long hours and little pay
- On average, Apple provides around 3% pay raises each year. This does not cover the increasing costs of living in Austin. It doesnâ€™t matter how great of an employee you are, you should expect 3%. There is no reason to work hard.
- Apple does not care about the city of Austin or the citizens that live here. Apple takes tax breaks and incentives, while continuing to white-wash any culture out of Austin, contribute to awful traffic patterns, and keeping overall city wages stagnant.
- Utilizing time off benefits is frowned upon. Workload sits for you to complete when you return, negating any kind of "refreshment" you feel from being away
- No room for promotions. Management does not care about development or helping you explore other opportunities. 
- Management is constantly talking about how much money our department has saved the company (weâ€™re talking millions of dollars), meanwhile a peer on my team is on food stamps.
- Many of my peers are struggling with mental health issues due to being overworked and not having enough time off. Appleâ€™s health benefits barely cover any type of treatment for mental health issues. Even the â€œtop tierâ€ health insurance plan does not cover widely accepted mental health treatment and instead insurance encourages you to take Xanax.
- When we had on-site doctors, they were low quality and constantly gaslight you
advice_to_mgmt: Remember that your employees are humans and many have families. We deserve to be treated better.

headline: The. Worst.
status:
4 January 2021
Helpful (1)
"The. Worst."
1.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Current Employee
pros: You get a paycheck and you get to work from home
cons: No managers or support even when customers are screaming at you. Many of my co workers are having mental health issues because of how this job is designed and Apple does not want to hear about it. It is so stressful. I've never worked in a place that I could not get support from a manager. It does not exist in this role. Imagine someone has purchased a $3000 laptop and it never arrived in the mail and they have been given the wrong info when they called before (and the time before that). Yep sorry no you can't speak to a manager because there aren't any and I'm working at home. It's just you and me on the phone and you're yelling at me and there's nothing I can do. For the first few weeks I felt like this was the second worst job I have ever had but now that I've done it for a few months, it's moved into the number one spot. I have nightmares and canâ€™t sleep most nights. I dread sitting at my desk and taking a call because you never know what youâ€™re going to get on the other end of the line. And the whole set up is right in the middle of my home so even when Iâ€™m not working, it sits there and I have to look at it. I canâ€™t get away.
advice_to_mgmt: Design this system differently so specialists can get a manager on the line to speak with customers who demand it. The world is different now and Apple needs to adapt.

Helpful (1)

4.0

Current Employee
pros: Working at Apple is great. the overall culture is good, people are happy to be here and there is a team environment. long term compensation is realistic and decent but not crazy.
cons: Enterprise leaders focused on device sales and not the Apple Experience and Culture. Current Batch of leaders (2020) have no idea what transformation is and have never sold it.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on what makes Apple-Apple. Stop measuring activity and requiring so many reports and data submission so you can BS your numbers to Tim. We don't negotiate deals since we have no control over pricing, quoting, billing or support. We are Business development not sales. revert back to a BizDev comp model that incentivizes doing what's right and the customer will follow. it's embarrassing asking how many will you buy this month, every month.

pros: Benefits, discounts, health insurance, and a 9-5 job Monday to Friday.
cons:
Hypocrisy is the main philosophy of this company. They tell people to not worry and do what they can but they fire a third of the new people before finishing their probation because they are not good enough or they don't bend on their knees enough.
You are even controlled when you pee, how much you pee and they even ask you if you pee day more than the usual one day. You have 7 minutes per day to go to the bathroom and don't you even dare to go if it is a busy day.
The micromanagement in this company is brutal, doesn't matter how much you do, you will be always asked for more, they are always in your back with a whip.
They will try to wash your brain, they will harass you, and prepare yourself to be the manager's Â´Â´favoriteÂ´Â´ if you want to get a higher position. And don't even dare to go to apply to a higher position if you don't want to be depressed as are half of the senior advisors.
advice_to_mgmt: Please go to a psychologist, you need it urgently, it is not normal how you treat your employees.

headline: Definitely not the same company after Steve Jobsâ€™ death!
status:

"Definitely not the same company after Steve Jobsâ€™ death!"
2.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: Supportive staff and management, as long as you only focus on metrics (sales & appointment times)
cons:
Apple Australia is SUCH a different company & culture than Apple in the US. Sales and service metrics are king, everything else falls by the wayside.
Donâ€™t call in sick or take a personal day for work-life balance, youâ€™ll be ostracized by leadership. 
Bullying is RAMPANT in Australian retail stores, when brought to leadershipâ€™s attention - they tell you that it must be you because youâ€™re not assuming positive intent. 
Favoritism is everywhere and not hidden - be one of the cool kids or youâ€™ll be left out of every opportunity.
advice_to_mgmt: Bring back Steveâ€™s vision, a fierce customer focus, and treat team members like part of the team. Get rid of the rampant bullying and favoritism and learn that harassment (however subtle) is never okay and should never be swept under the rug by HR after complaints.

headline: Good in theory
status:
2 November 2020
"Good in theory"
3.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Current Employee
pros: The larger company has good values, great benefits.
cons: Company claims to better about things like diversity and inclusion, respecting employees time and work life balance, etc. but their actions speak louder than their words. Non-receptive to feedback. Working for them felt like being gaslight- they would promise to change, say they care and even go so far as to make us hug and say they "loved" us, which was weird and cultish. I observed and experienced being tokenized as a minority. There were many complaints of pay inequity, as well as HR complaints that ended in HR telling the parties to "talk it out" internally when it felt clear to me (and others) that they should have been punishable offenses. Leadership would routinely act similar to politicians, making promises they didn't keep. Many people, likely trying to get promoted, had a facade of niceness which became exhuasting to be around.

headline: A fantastic place to work in decline.
status:
31 October 2020
"A fantastic place to work in decline."
3.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Current Employee
pros:
-Amazing team and culture.
-Great benefits.
-Great for personal development.
-Great for students, a lot of time flexibility.
cons:
-Management can be incredibly mixed. It's not uncommon to see managers give incredibly different treatment for customers. 
-Management doesn't fully understand aspects of the store and how it functions. 
-The stores are focusing way more on upselling customers
-Increasingly higher targets to reach
-Very political workplace. Not necessarily a negative thing, but can be jarring for a retail job.
-Minimal career opportunities. Most will never progress to manager level.
advice_to_mgmt: Remember why your staff retention was so good a few years back and have a look at why it's been falling so consistently. Not everything is up-selling and psuedo KPI's.

pros:
The management team at my store stood behind the employees when altercations arose between us and customers. 
Competitive pay
Benefits and incentives are absolutely wonderful for both full-time and part-time employees
Employee Stock Purchase Plan
Employees are gifted shares after working at the company for a certain amount of time
cons: As a Technical Specialist, you're helping stressed-out customers solve their technology issues. Sometimes you don't know what the problem is and you'll likely be in a stressful customer interaction more than once, each and every day.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to exercise good judgement in standing by your employees as they make decisions to help or deny service to customers.

pros: Great benefits. Fair pay. Wonderfully diverse culture. Good bonuses.
cons: Typical corporate bureaucracy. Advancement is RARELY based on merit and experience. The constant drive for new talent is present in all positions so it is FAR more likely that someone from outside the org will end up your boss than someone whose been promoted. Or it will be someone internal but was transferred from another department. Individual achievements are not recognized. Your success is Appleâ€™s success so know that you are a small cog in a big machine that wonâ€™t miss you when you leave. Apple will engulf every aspect of your life. More relatives will call you asking for help with their products than relatives would call you if you won the lottery.
advice_to_mgmt: Fight for your teamâ€™s individualsâ€™ professional development more than headcount.

headline: Poor collaboration, incurious engineers, exploitative company
status:
15 October 2020
"Poor collaboration, incurious engineers, exploitative company"
2.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Current Employee
pros:
- Decent benefits and compensation for US based engineers
- That's it. That's why they get two stars instead of one
cons:
- Most team members I've worked with don't take pride in their work
- Directors and leaders often make decisions without consulting their teams, and then expect the team to execute on their commitments
- Discourse is usually based on making other people happy instead of making the best engineering decision
- Bugs, especially performance bugs, often go unfixed
- Leadership often has no concept of how to test products well or what kind of talent to hire to make that possible
- Most people only want to do the minimum amount of work to make their manager happy
- Will underpay labor if they can get away with it, especially outside the US
advice_to_mgmt: The biggest change that would improve Apple's performance would be to make a much larger effort to let engineers work collaboratively instead of skate around their security guidelines. Apple should stop being so obsessed with having secret launches that don't even matter because most of their features have already been implemented by competitors. I have literally spent 8 work months of this year on product security, and it's not even my job.

headline: Decent for Big Retail
status:
18 September 2020
Helpful (2)
"Decent for Big Retail"
4.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: Their training for retail is particularly robust. I didn't find it difficult to go from training to on-the-floor, but it was a 3 day training process. They offer nice discounts and benefits available to those who are seasonal or part-time employees. You will not be able to avail of ALL discounts that Apple offers but there are quite a few you can manage to take advantage from while working there. I think your experience being a product specialist will also heavily rely on when you work at Apple and where. I was hired as a seasonal employee for the winter holidays in Los Angeles. It can be brutal with tourists bombarding you with question after question about discounts you are obviously unable to give them. I found the best people to work with to be the coworkers. They are diverse because Apple wants you to be diverse, which is nice, except that Apple's illusion of caring for diversity pretty much stops once it goes beyond the retail floor.
cons: The kool aid drinking is beyond imaginable. It is cult like. They push real hard the sentiment that Apple is The Best Company in the World to Work For and Look At How Much We Care About Things. I think the company genuinely has more compassion that a few other tech giants but that's not saying much, to be honest. Also some of the store managers have an over-inflated ego about being store managers for an Apple store. But whatever floats their boats I guess.
advice_to_mgmt: Please hire more diverse employees in... like... your C-level positions. It doesn't really mean anything when the people running your company are about as spicy as polonaise but you're proud of how diverse your retail employees are. It just means you like to exploit our image.

headline: Just above average pay for very long hours and being pushed to your limit.
status:
29 September 2020
Helpful (1)
"Just above average pay for very long hours and being pushed to your limit."
3.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros:
You get to see the product road map up to 6-8 years out and it can be fun playing with new technology. You get to make awesome designs for great people.

You will learn a lot. Take advantage of their school reimbursement programs and any skill programs offered.

It will be the highest design standards you will work with in your career. Material, tolerances and finishes must be perfect.

Max our your stock options and when vested 401k.

You will learn cutting edge design methods and have excellent standards and practices.

Overtime is good, this can even go to double time in some cases. Having an extra 2-4 hours of overtime a day adds up. Just make sure to pace yourself and take care of your health.

There is always something to do.

If you love the brand it will draw you in and you will have a role in bringing Apple's products to life.

Your work will have an impact on millions of people.

You will do the work of a higher paid position so it will be nice to get that experience.

If you are doing good use this to get a higher position elsewhere, it will help you advance your career faster.
cons:
Management tends to be very self centered, not as much focused on growing your career but in growing their own. This can often cause tension as lots of people are vying for attention of higher ups. Expect to do all manner to tasks to help the team and your manager. Some will be menial but they will lead to more fun and complex projects over time. Make sure you do all your basic work before seeking to get to advanced work. 

There is not a lot of ownership of responsibility in management. Often they will kick downward. For example if they made a call on a design direction and it turns out that the higher ups do not like it they will blame the worker following their request in my experience. Do not count on accountability, however I would recommend if your manager is rude or does something out of line let Apple HR know immediately. It will save you a lot of hassle down the line.

Politics is huge at Apple. Pay very close attention. People will pretend to be your friend or interested in your work to make a connection. If you get too popular with higher ups in a different team management can punish you, even if you were doing your job. Have a pulse on politics. Rank is big at Apple.

Apple's biggest flaw is they rush themselves to the breaking point where for no reason. Often cutting already tight timelines for small reasons rather than give someone an additional 8 hours to refine a design. They can set the deadlines and standards but they often push people far beyond reasonable limits and in some cases the deadlines can be changed just as easily as they are set. In some cases I have worked 28 hours straight on a prototype that could just have easily been move out one day. This creates a scramble culture where you will be under a lot of stress often. You will be blamed for not doing work fast enough when often you can be given timelines that are not physically possible. In those cases be prepared to set expectations so you will not be taken advantage of.

The average day is 12 hours. During a build it typically goes until the project is done. This mind you will get you a 'meets expectations' on your review. Doing above average work is average for Apple standards. You need to go above even that or have a good political connection for the next level.

Often you will have to leave the company/position you are in to get a promotion of any value. Its such a waste that Apple does not help grow people's careers especially after investing so much time into them.

You will often be asked to do the work of others and get no credit for it, even if you do your own expiration be careful as your manager may take your idea. Document everything you do, this will help.

You will often be pushed to commit everything to work and be accessed at all hours of the day. Be careful in how you set boundaries as this can often lead to you not being seen as serious.

You will often do the work at a higher level than your current position but not be paid more for it. You will often help people make extremely complicated projects and get no real recognition for it.
advice_to_mgmt:
Recognize ambition and try not to make the career development of others about advancing your own career. Help build others up rather than try and take credit for the work of others.

Listen when people tell you something is wrong or if the person you manage is being bullied. Seriously, listen and help.

When you say you will push back and help with insanely tight deadlines, actually do it. I cannot say how many time we would have a meeting where we would all say the timeline is impossible, our manager would say "Yep I'll bring that up when we meet," then we all met and they would not say a word when the designer laid out their expectations and timeline.

Current Employee
pros: They pay a little better than other retail stores, plus have good benefits with a VERY positive and friendly management team who cares about your experience just as much as the customer's experience.
cons: It's hard to move up in the company because so many people apply for the same positions that are all just as qualified as you. Apple is good with not playing "favorites" but at the end of the day, the person who gets the promotion will be the person who networks better. Movement is about management liking you more than how well you perform. I don't see a way around that one. EVERYONE loves Apple who works there and gives it there all. There is no shortage of talent!
advice_to_mgmt: The only feedback I would give is around days off. I'm an employee who has a near-perfect time and attendance. I'd love a normal schedule that doesn't change so I can plan my life around it. That would make my experience MUCH better.

headline: If you're easily stessed, don't work here.
status:
19 September 2020
Helpful (1)
"If you're easily stessed, don't work here."
2.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Current Employee
pros: Great pay, benefits for LGBT families including healthcare
cons: Constantly shifting management, difficult to advance,
advice_to_mgmt:
At home advisors are micro-managed on so many different numbers. Your manager will constantly tell you there is something you can improve on. I've found that you can work for this company for a decade and still be stuck doing the same tasks in the same position. 

There will be peers you meet that moved up quickly and management will tell you itâ€™s your fault if you havenâ€™t transitioned into a higher role. You will have the same manager for about 6 months max, then they will take a leave of absence or go to a new department- so youâ€™re stuck proving yourself to someone new. 

If you are chat support, they will expect you to help up to 3 individuals at once (4 if you are consulting with another department) and respond within 2 minutes while customers are asking â€œHello, are you there?â€ and you are told to lie if the customer asks if weâ€™re helping multiple people.

If you are not fast enough, they will question your ability and recommend you get medical help. Completely absurd.

Repair pricing for all devices is expensive for the average person. This truly is a luxury brand and you will find out soon enough when customers cannot afford the ridiculous prices this company wants to charge everyone for out of warranty repairs.

Bonuses are never received, but there are annual performance reviews typically followed by a 40 cent pay raise and heavily taxed Restricted Stock Units that you cannot touch for years. You will make good money working here, but you will be expected to devote all your time to helping customers in an extremely stressful, fast paced environment while staring at white space on a screen all day.

The major takeaway working for Apple- is that youâ€™re working for a huge corporate conglomerate that overcharges for everything, and furthers capitalism in a way that has made humans codependent on our screens and immediate gratification.

Former Employee
pros:
feel great pride in seeing your creations in people's hands
good compensation
job security
opportunities for advancement
work with high quality engineers
cons:
work in a silo
focus on execution with little room for exploration and experimentation
learn what's going on at the company by reading Appleinsider.com and Macrumors.com
you become very specialized and lose skills outside your narrow job duties
you become anonymous and few people outside your team know who you are or what you've accomplished
advice_to_mgmt: Give top people some opportunities for exposure outside our teams. Let us show off some of our work at HotChips or other conferences so people know what cool stuff we have done. If not a public conference, at least an internal tech conference.

headline: Excellent employer, however culture was degrading
status:
20 August 2020
"Excellent employer, however culture was degrading"
4.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros: Excellent employer, great pay, amazing benefits with low deductible. Training staff and process is incredible. I absolutely loved my time with Apple and they gave me an amazing opportunity to grow myself both personally and professionally.
cons: Degraded culture, little managerial discretion, entry-level employees get away with absenteeism and poor ethical performance. However much of this is due to the large size of the company and court rulings that favor poor performing employees because "Apple is so big is can take the hit when an employee calls out repeatedly" however what they fail to realize is that when 20% of the staff is calling out repeatedly, it impacts the customer experience and makes managing attendance a nightmare. Additionally, there is very little growth that has been occurring at Apple for the last 3-4 for years. Some entry level employees that have completed apprenticeships and proven they are managerial material have had little to no opportunities as there have been no openings.

headline: Its not what you think....
status:
20 August 2020
Helpful (1)
"Its not what you think...."
2.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros:
- Fitness allowance
- Worked in a very talented collaborative team, can't emphasise this enough!
- Plenty of opportunity to level-up communication skills internally and with customers particularly in a flagship store
- Working in dynamic situations under competing pressures means similar situations in other contexts are a doddle now
- Attention to detail and people centred approach (to customer service & technology) Have not found this at other companies
cons:
- HUGE disconnect between marketing and reality particularly in regards to diversity and inclusion. Sadly there's no real commitment to seriously support and celebrate all employees, address genuine disparities or to listen and act on feedback in this regard whether on a store level or Cupertino.
-Management: lack knowledge and competencies across all areas of store including in customer conflict deescalation and resolution, some have bullying/gate-keeperish line management style, make decisions without input of people on the ground, physical and mental wellbeing of staff is not a priority.
- Cult like company culture leads to inability to publicly express a range of thoughts and emotions even outside of work
- high turnover particularly of shop floor colleagues particularly at Xmas
- Poor life/work balance due to scheduling
- No real opportunities exist connecting corporate to retail arm
- Pay is extremely low for what you actually do
- Upwards progression non existent due to favouritism and bias
- Made to feel very disposable and exploited
- Told Metrics/KPIs are not so important when you join but you soon realise they are seen as most important thing - even above customer experience
- Genius Bar 'Resets' are supposed to be a short well-deserved rest but instead become the primary way training is delivered
advice_to_mgmt: You will haemorrhage talent if you do not invest in development and progression, whilst compensating and recognising your team's passion and craft. 'Positive intent' and 'feedback' are used so selectively disadvantaging some of the most vulnerable in the team. Listen and include your employees more and stop infantilising them -we are the one's physically running the show.

headline: Right for the wrong reasons
role: Int Designer, Senior User Experience Designer, User Experience Engineer
status:
11 August 2020
Helpful (1)
"Right for the wrong reasons"
3.0
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Former Employee
pros:
- (subjective) As each of the 'most desireable' FANG companies has their own culture, Apple has theirs. Its a bit more low-key, professional and relaxed.
- after the initial shock of "I work at Apple now" fades away, work is work and your satisfaction/stress level will vary depending on your role, department, skill set and organization. I transferred between 3 different organizations - some very political, others like family. Sometimes within an org, 1 managers style (understanding, laid back - just expects quality work on time etc) would be a complete opposite of my coworkers under another manager (9-5 run like an agency)
- if you're ambitious there is opportunity - but also know there is a sautÃ©s quo and you are taking a risk. its up to you whether or not its worth it.
- looks great on your resume
cons: Alot of politics, I've seen entire agencies brought in for single projects where the end result was scraped. I've seen managers hire relatives and Apple outsources their 'investigations' department who get paid by how many people they accuse of violating policies.
advice_to_mgmt:
Not to all management, but to those who contract security teams and to whoever made the decision that your personal iCloud account becomes you work account. you find this out during orientation but by then its too late to create a new Apple ID.

There's no opportunity for separation of "church and state" and as I experienced a "zero-tolerance" policy was enacted, there was no announcement and I was interrogated for violating it after being an above average (based on performance reviews) employee for ~4 years.
